Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Bena M. Tshishiku is "Algebraic Topology: Characteristic Classes, Fiber Bundles, and Lie Groups." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Soren Galatius.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has produced new results in geometry and topology, specifically in the study of fiber bundles and their characteristic classes. This includes the construction of new characteristic classes for manifold bundles, and the establishment of new connections between the theory of these characteristic classes and index theory and arithmetic groups. In a related direction, in this work we have found new obstructions to Nielsen realization problems building off of work of Morita and also Farrell-Jones. During this work, four research articles have been published and two more have been submitted for publication. Furthermore, we have written two survey articles (one on surface bundles and one on Nielsen realization problems) in an effort to increase research activity in these areas.

The work was completely primarily while the PI was a postdoctoral fellow at Stanford University and Harvard University. This work has promoted collaborations with researchers in several different areas including algebraic topology and homotopy theory (Alexander Kupers and Jeffrey Giansiracusa), geometric topology and high-dimensional manifolds (Mauricio Bustamanta and Manuel Krannich), low-dimensional topology and geometric group theory (Nick Salter and Genevieve Walsh). The results gathered during this project have been widely shared in talks at 24 conferences and in 37 seminars, both in the United States and abroad (France, Germany, Poland, Denmark, Ireland, UK, Canada).

The PI is currently using the work completed during this project as a basis for engaging graduate students in research and undergraduate students in reading courses in areas of geometry and topology.
